text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Irish cheddar spring onion
biscuits that's right I'm featuring
these beautiful biscuits for two very
good reasons first of all st. Patrick's
Day is right around the corner and a
basket of these sure would look
beautiful next all that Irish food but
also I've never been completely thrilled
with what people pass off as cheddar
biscuits since in general I find them
dense and uninteresting
so bowring a technique from our French
pastry friends we're gonna hopefully
remedy that situation so let's go ahead
get started with what's basically a
fairly standard biscuit dough and for me
that's gonna start with a couple cups of
self-rising flour which is nothing more
than regular flour with baking powder
and salt milled right into it
and while this is very easy to make
yourself and I'll give you those
measurements on the blog for whatever
reasons biscuits work better if you use
this stuff instead of making your own
and then to this because we're gonna be
using buttermilk we're also gonna toss
in a little bit of baking soda which is
alkaline and when that mixes with the
acidic buttermilk it creates bubbles oh
yeah it's all very scientific so we'll
go ahead and mix in a little bit of
baking soda at which point we're ready
to is they say in the business cut in
the butter so I'm gonna toss in exactly
seven tablespoons of very cold butter
that as you can see I cut into slices
and then we'll take one of these wire
pastry blenders and go ahead and cut
that in and if it looks like I'm having
a little bit of trouble getting that
started I am because I froze the butter
ahead of time alright when it comes to
biscuits and similar-type dough's the
colder the butter the better okay what
we're trying to accomplish here as
millions of little pieces of cold butter
covered in flour and not a whole bunch
of butter and flour mashed together okay
so even though it's gonna take you a
little longer to get started very cold
possibly frozen butter is the best way
to go here and as you'll see once you
get it started it's not too bad and will
continue to work that over with our wire
pastry cutter or pastry blender some
people call them until we have something
that looks like this and I never know
exactly how to describe this so people
say do it until it resembles coarse
crumbs but I'm not sure that's a great
description but hey thank God for video
just do until it looks like this and
what we'll do once that's been
accomplished is make a little well in
the center and pour in our ice-cold
buttermilk and we'll go ahead and take
our fork and mix that in
and if you've made biscuits with me
before you know I don't like to mix
everything very thoroughly in the bowl
okay what we want to do is just stir it
until it starts to come together like
this and once it just starts to pull
together and reaches that shaggy dough
stage what we'll do is stop mixing flour
our work surface and finish mixing on
the table and then the initial stages
here all we're doing is kind of pressing
that into a roughly shaped rectangle and
by the way if it seems super wet and you
can't do this add a little bit of flour
and on the other hand if it seems a
little too dry we'll just sprinkle in a
little bit of buttermilk until it comes
together so that's just you making
biscuits but anyway somehow someway we
will gather that dough together and
press it into a rectangle at which point
we will grab our bench scraper which by
the way you must own and we will fold
that in thirds and then sort of flatten
that back out with our hands and just
like virtually all dough related
operations if it's too sticky add a
little bit of flour so right there I
determined it was a little too wet and
sticky so I dusted it with some flour
and by the time we get that press back
out into some kind of rectangular shape
our dough should basically now be
properly mixed okay had we mix it
further in the bowl at this point it
might be over mixed but anyway at this
point I'm going to dust it with a little
more flour and then switch to a rolling
pin because before we start applying our
cheese and onions we want to go ahead
and roll this out to about a half inch
thick or maybe just a little thicker
than that so basically we're just gonna
roll that out until it resemble
something like this and then what we'll
do once that's been accomplished to
sprinkle over about a quarter cup of
freshly shredded Irish cheddar and then
in addition to the cheese we'll also
scatter over some spring onions which
the rest of the year we call green
onions but this time of the year
especially in Irish recipes we call them
spring onions and then what we'll do
once we have that cheesed and onion is
take our bench scraper and fold that in
thirds and once that's been folded up
we'll kind of press that down and
believe it or not we're actually gonna
repeat that process one more time so
again we'll dust with flour if necessary
and I should mention when it comes to
biscuit dough you can always add the
scraps back in okay just press them
right in and those are gonna totally
disappear into the rest of the goodness
but anyway like I said we're gonna roll
that back out
and apply the rest of our cheese and
green onions oops spring onions and by
the way just because I'm using Irish
cheddar and a cheap attempt to convince
people this is an Irish recipe that does
not mean you have to use it okay pretty
much your favorite cheddar is gonna work
here so use whatever you want as long as
you promise to grade it yourself but
anyway once we have our second edition
of cheese and onions in we will fold in
thirds one last time which point is
ready to roll out and cut into biscuits
before the record there was absolutely
no reason for me to pick off that little
piece of spring onion but I did it
anyway sometimes you just can't help
yourself but anyway we're gonna go ahead
and roll that out to approximately a
half inch thick and if you want taller
biscuits just make fewer biscuits and
don't roll it out so thin but because
I'm adding cheese I don't want these to
be doughy in the middle so I do tend to
roll them out a little thinner than
regular biscuits and then once that said
if you want to make life easy just cut
these into squares and bake them but
apparently I didn't want this to be easy
plus nature much prefer circles over
squares this is one of the few things we
understand about the universe so I'm
gonna go ahead and use a round cutter to
punch these out but either will work and
of course that's up to you you are after
all the Sylvester Stallone of what some
may refer to as a Blarney scone but
anyway we're gonna cut up our biscuits
which will always lead to trimmings and
in this case probably more than I wanted
and while they won't come out as good as
the first batch we can totally press
this extra back together and eventually
roll it out into some kind of similar
thickness and cut the rest and yes I did
roll out this piece of little thinner so
I could cut for biscuits which of course
will have those cook up a little bit
differently but not so much differently
that it would cause a problem but anyway
regardless of whether they were cut from
Virginia or from a bunch of smooshed
together scraps once our biscuits are
cut we'll transfer those onto a
parchment lined baking sheet and then
what we'll do to fish these off before
they go in the oven is brush the tops
lightly with buttermilk as well as
finish with a couple teaspoons of
shredded cheddar on the top of each one
and for you fans of hearing
super-obvious things we're adding that
for taste and appearance and that's it
once our buttermilk and cheese has been
applied we can go ahead and transfer
those into the center of a 400 degree
oven for about 20 minutes or so or until
our biscuits are cooked through and look
something like this man
look good and very cheesy and as you can
see even though our dough is pretty thin
these really did puff up nicely and we
have some very visible and quite
provocative layers and at this point you
could play that fun game pick out the
ones we made from the scrapped dough so
sure a few might come out not quite as
beautiful as the other ones but that's
okay a slightly imperfect cheddar
biscuit is better than no cheddar
biscuit at all I think we can all agree
on that so I went ahead and transferred
those beauties to a rack to cool before
breaking into one to see how we did and
speaking of imperfect let me pick out
the worst one and test that one and if
this one's good I know all the rest are
gonna be amazing and check it out it was
good it was light and flaky with just
the right ratio a chewiness to
tenderness and crispy in all the right
spots so I was extremely happy with how
these came out and I really do think
this layering method is superior to just
mixing the cheese and onions into the
dough which is the most common way to do
these I'm looking to you national
crustacean based restaurant chain but
anyway I loved how these came out so I
transfer those into a towel line basket
for the mandatory biscuits in a basket
shot and those are now ready to pair
with things like corned beef and cabbage
or a beautiful Irish stew or if you're
one of these people into hot carbon car
back ssin these would even be great
served next to coal cotton or is it
colcannon
I'm not sure I'm still trying to figure
out if it's Celtic or Celtic but anyway
that's it whether you're gonna make
these for st. Patrick's Day or just some
time you want a delicious cheesy and
fairly awesome biscuit I really do hope
you give these a try soon so head over
to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual
and as always enjoy
